revision.comment: rv - Catholic/Protestant/etc. are distinctions relevant to later time periods. During the time period discussed here, it was just Christian.
revision.text:
{{Infobox Birth control |name = Coitus interruptus |image = |width = |caption = |bc_type = Behavioral |date_first_use = Ancient |rate_type = Failure |perfect_failure% = 4 |typical_failure% = 15-28 |duration_effect = |reversibility = Yes |user_reminders = Dependent upon self-control. Urinating between acts of sexual intercourse helps clear sperm from urethra. |clinic_interval = None |STD_protection_YesNo = No |periods = |benefits = No side effects |weight_gain_loss = |risks = |medical_notes = }} '''Coitus interruptus''', also known as '''withdrawal''' or the '''pull-out method''', is a technique in which a man withdraws his penis prior to [[ejaculation]] during [[sexual intercourse]], with the [[semen]] being [[ejaculation|ejaculated]] outside of and away from the [[vagina]]. It is and has been widely used for at least 2,000 years as a method of [[contraception]]. This method was used by an estimated 38 million couples worldwide in 1991.{{cite journal |author=Rogow D, Horowitz S |title=Withdrawal: a review of the literature and an agenda for research |journal=Studies in family planning |volume=26 |issue=3 |pages=140–53 |year=1995 |pmid=7570764 |doi=10.2307/2137833}}, which cites:
:[[Population Action International]] (1991). "A Guide to Methods of Birth Control." Briefing Paper No. 25, Washington, D. C. Some medical professionals view withdrawal as an ineffective method of birth control.{{cite journal |author=Creatsas G |title=Sexuality: sexual activity and contraception during adolescence | journal = Curr Opin Obstet Gynecol | volume = 5 | issue = 6 |pages=774–83 |year=1993|pmid = 8286689}} ==History== Perhaps the oldest documentation of the use of the withdrawal method to avoid pregnancy is the story of [[Onan]] in the [[Hebrew Bible]]. This text is believed to have been written down over 2,500 years ago.{{cite web |last=Adams |first=Cecil |authorlink=Cecil Adams |title=Who wrote the Bible? (Part 1) |work=The Straight Dope |publisher=Creative Loafing Media, Inc. |date=2002-01-07 |url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/1985/who-wrote-the-bible-part-1 |accessdate=2009-07-24}} Societies in the ancient civilizations of [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] and [[Roman Empire|Rome]] preferred small families and are known to have practiced a variety of birth control methods.{{rp|12,16-17}} There are references that have led historians to believe withdrawal was sometimes used as birth control.{{cite book |author=Bullough, Vern L. |title=Encyclopedia of birth control |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location=Santa Barbara, Calif |year=2001 |pages=74–75 |isbn=1-57607-181-2 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=XuX-MGTZnJoC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74 |accessdate=2009-07-24}} However, these societies viewed birth control as a woman's responsibility, and the only well-documented contraception methods were female-controlled devices (both possibly effective, such as [[pessary|pessaries]], and ineffective, such as [[amulet]]s).{{cite book | first=Aine | last=Collier | year=2007 | title=The Humble Little Condom: A History | publisher=Prometheus Books | location=Amherst, NY | isbn=978-1-59102-556-6}}{{rp|17,23}} After the [[decline of the Roman Empire]] in the 400s, contraceptive practices fell out of use in Europe; the use of contraceptive pessaries, for example, is not documented again until the fifteenth century. If withdrawal were used during the Roman Empire, knowledge of the practice may have been lost during its decline.{{rp|33,42}} A contributing factor to the loss of contraceptive knowledge was the rise of [[Christianity]], which considered all forms of birth control to be [[sin]]s.{{rp|35,37}} From the eighteenth century until the development of modern methods, withdrawal was one of the most popular methods of birth control in Europe, America, and elsewhere. == Effectiveness == Like many methods of birth control, reliable effectiveness is achieved only by correct and consistent use. Observed failure rates of withdrawal vary depending on the population being studied: studies have found actual failure rates of 15-28% per year.{{cite book | first=John | last=Kippley | coauthors=Sheila Kippley | year=1996 | title=The Art of Natural Family Planning | edition=4th addition | publisher=The Couple to Couple League | location=Cincinnati, OH | isbn=0-926412-13-2 | pages=146 }}, which cites:
:{{cite journal |last=Guttmacher Institute |title=Choice of Contraceptives | journal = The Medical Letter on Drugs and Therapeutics | volume = 34 |pages=111–114 |year=1992 | doi = 10.1016/j. {{cite book | first=RA | last=Hatcher | coauthors=Trussel J, Stewart F, et al. | year=1994 | title=Contraceptive Technology | edition=Sixteenth Revised | publisher=Irvington Publishers | location=New York | isbn=0-8290-3171-5 }} In comparison [[combined oral contraceptive pill|the pill]] has an actual use failure rate of 2-8%,{{cite journal | author=Audet MC, Moreau M, Koltun WD, Waldbaum AS, Shangold G, Fisher AC, Creasy GW | title=Evaluation of contraceptive efficacy and cycle control of a transdermal contraceptive patch vs an oral contraceptive: a randomized controlled trial | journal=JAMA | year=2001 | pages=2347–54 | volume=285 | issue=18 | pmid=11343482 | url=http://www.contraceptiononline.org/slides/slide01.cfm?q=pearl+index&dpg=6 | format=Slides of comparative efficacy] | doi=10.1001/jama.285.18.2347}}
{{cite web | author =Guttmacher Institute | authorlink =Guttmacher Institute | url =http://www.agi-usa.org/pubs/fb_contr_use.html | title =Contraceptive Use | work =Facts in Brief | publisher =Guttmacher Institute | accessdate =2005-05-10}} - see table ''First-Year Contraceptive Failure Rates'' while the [[intrauterine device]] (IUD) has an actual use failure rate of 0.8%. The [[condom]] has an actual use failure rate of 10-18%. However some authors suggest that actual effectiveness of withdrawal could be similar to effectiveness of condoms, and this area needs further research.{{cite journal |author=Jones RK, Fennell J, Higgins JA, Blanchard K |title=Better than nothing or savvy risk-reduction practice? The importance of withdrawal |journal=Contraception |volume=79 |issue=6 |pages=407–10 |year=2009 |month=June |pmid=19442773 |doi=10.1016/j.contraception.2008.12.008 |url=http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/journals/reprints/Contraception79-407-410.pdf |accessdate=2009-07-23 |format=PDF}} (see [[Comparison of birth control methods]]) For couples that use coitus interruptus correctly at every act of intercourse, the failure rate is 4% per year. In comparison the pill has a perfect-use failure rate of 0.3%, and the IUD has a perfect-use failure rate of 0.6%. The condom has a perfect-use failure rate of 2%.{{cite book | first=RA | last=Hatcher | coauthors=Trussel J, Stewart F, et al. | year=2000 | title=Contraceptive Technology | edition=18th | publisher=Ardent Media | location=New York | isbn=0-9664902-6-6 | url=http://www.contraceptivetechnology.com/table.html }} The primary cause of failure of the withdrawal method is the lack of self-control of those using it. Poor timing of the withdrawal can result in semen on the [[vulva]], which can easily migrate into the female reproductive tract. Some medical professionals view withdrawal as an ineffective method of birth control. In contrast, a recent study in Iran found that provinces with higher rates of withdrawal use do not have higher fertility rates, and that the contribution of withdrawal use to unintended pregnancies is not markedly different from that of other commonly used methods such as the pill or condom.{{cite paper |author=Amir H. Mehryar, A. Aghajanian, B. Delavar, H. Eini-Zinab, & Shahla Kazemipour |title=Continuing use of a traditional method (withdrawal) in a high contraceptive prevalence country, Iran: Correlates and consequences |publisher=Ministry of Science, Research and Technology, Iran |year=2005 |url=http://iussp2005.princeton.edu/download.aspx?submissionId=50785 |accessdate=2006-09-14 }} It has been suggested that the [[pre-ejaculate]] ("Cowper's fluid") emitted by the penis prior to ejaculation normally contains [[Spermatozoon|spermatozoa]] (sperm cells), which would compromise the effectiveness of the method.{{cite web |first=Roger W. |last=Harms |title=Can pre-ejaculation fluid cause pregnancy? |work=Women's health: Expert answers |publisher=MayoClinic.com |url=http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/birth-control/an00197 |date=2007-09-20 |accessdate=2009-07-15 }}{{cite web |first=Tracee |last=Cornforth |title=How effective is withdrawal as a birth control method? |work=About.com: Women's Health |url=http://womenshealth.about.com/cs/birthcontro1/a/withdrawalbircn.htm |date=2003-12-02 |accessdate=2009-07-15 }} However, several small studies{{cite journal |last=Zukerman |first=Z. | coauthors = Weiss D.B. Orvieto R. |title=Short Communication: Does Preejaculatory Penile Secretion Originating from Cowper's Gland Contain Sperm? | journal = Journal of Assisted Reproduction and Genetics | volume = 20 | issue = 4 |pages=157–159 |month=April | year=2003 | pmid = 12762415 | doi = 10.1023/A:1022933320700 }}{{cite journal |author=Free M, Alexander N |title=Male contraception without prescription. A reevaluation of the condom and coitus interruptus |journal=Public Health Rep |volume=91 |issue=5 |pages=437–45 |year=1976 |pmid=824668 |url=http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/picrender.fcgi?artid=1440560&blobtype=pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-03-06}}{{cite journal |title=Researchers find no sperm in pre-ejaculate fluid | journal = Contraceptive Technology Update | volume = 14 | issue = 10 |pages=154–156 |month=October | year=1993 | pmid = 12286905 | doi = 10.1016/j.{{cite web|author=Clark, S.|year=Sep 1981|title=An examination of the sperm content of human pre-ejaculatory fluid|publisher=[Unpublished]|url=http://www.popline.org/docs/0813/041933.html}} have failed to find any viable sperm in the fluid. While no large conclusive studies have been done, it is now believed the primary cause of method (correct-use) failure is the pre-ejaculate fluid picking up sperm from a previous ejaculation.{{cite web |title=Withdrawal Method |work=Planned Parenthood |month=March | year=2004 | url =http://www.plannedparenthood.com/health-topics/birth-control/withdrawal-pull-out-method-4218.htm |accessdate=2008-03-28 }} For this reason, it is recommended that users of withdrawal have the male partner urinate between ejaculations, to clear the urethra of sperm, and wash any ejaculate from objects that might come near the woman's vulva (e.g. hands and penis).{{cite web |last=Delvin |first=David |title=Coitus interruptus (Withdrawal method) |work=NetDoctor.co.uk |date=2005-01-17 |url=http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/sex_relationships/facts/coitusinterruptus.htm |accessdate=2006-07-13 }} == Advantages == The advantage of coitus interruptus is that it can be used by people who have objections to or do not have access to other forms of contraception. (Some men prefer it so they can avoid possible adverse effects of hormonal contraceptives on their partners.{{cite journal|author=Ortayli, N et al.|title=Why Withdrawal? Why not withdrawal? Men's perspectives|journal=Reproductive Health Matters|year=2005|issue=13|volume=25|pages=164–73|pmid=16035610|doi=10.1016/S0968-8080(05)25175-3}}) Some women also prefer this method over hormonal contraception to avoid adverse effects such as depression, mood swings, vaginal dryness, decreased libido, and headaches, among others. It has no direct monetary cost, requires no artificial devices, has no physical side effects, can be practiced without a prescription or medical consultation, and provides no barriers to stimulation. == Disadvantages == Compared to the other common reversible methods of contraception such as IUDs, hormonal contraceptives and male condoms, coitus interruptus is less effective at preventing pregnancy. As a result, it is also less cost-effective than many more effective methods: although the method itself has little direct cost, users have a greater chance of incurring the risks and expenses of pregnancy and child-birth. Only models that assume all couples practise perfect use of the method find cost savings associated with the choice of withdrawal as a birth control method.{{cite journal|journal = American Journal of Public Health|title=Economic value of contraception|author = James Trusell, et al.|date = April 1995|volume = 85|issue = 4|pages= 494–503|url=http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/85/4/494.pdf|doi = 10.2105/AJPH.85.4.494}} The method is largely ineffective in the prevention of [[STDs]], like [[HIV]], since [[pre-ejaculate]] may carry viral particles or bacteria which may infect the partner if this fluid comes in contact with mucous membranes. However, a reduction in the volume of bodily fluids exchanged during intercourse may reduce the likelihood of disease transmission compared to using no method due to the smaller number of pathogens present. The method may be difficult for some couples to use. The interruption of intercourse may leave some couples sexually frustrated or dissatisfied.{{cite web |title=Coitus Interruptus (Withdrawal) |work=Abstinence & Natural Birth Control Methods |publisher=Sexually Transmitted Disease Resource |year=2006 |url=http://www.sexual-health-resource.org/natural_birth_control.htm#withdrawal |accessdate=2006-09-05 }} [[Masters and Johnson]] considered withdrawal as a means to developing [[sexual dysfunction|sexual problems]], e.g. [[premature ejaculation]].{{cite book|author=Masters, W.H., & Johnson, V.E.|year=1970|title=Human sexual inadequacy|location=Boston|publisher=Little, Brown and Company}} The same opinion was shared by [[Poland|Polish]] [[sexology|sexologist]], Kazimierz Imieliński.{{cite book|author=Imieliński, Z.|year=1986|title=Zarys seksuologii i seksiatrii|location=Warsaw|publisher=Państwowy Zakład Wydawnictw Lekarskich}} However neither of those authors refers to any scientific research on this topic, there could not be found any research to backup those theories[[PubMed]] search revels no research articles on premature ejaculation and withdrawal, see search results with query: [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?db=pubmed&orig_db=pubmed&term=%28%22premature%20ejaculation%22[Title/Abstract]%29%20AND%20%28%22withdrawal%22[Title/Abstract]%20OR%20%22coitus%20interruptus%22[Title/Abstract]%29&cmd=&cmd_current=|("premature ejaculation"[Title/Abstract]) AND ("withdrawal"[Title/Abstract] OR "coitus interruptus"[Title/Abstract])]., and health risks connected with withdrawal are considered as myths.{{cite web|author=INFO Project|title=Contraceptive Myths and Counseling Messages|year=2007|publisher=International Planned Parenthood Federation|url=http://www.ippf.org/en/Resources/Contraception/}} == Prevalence == Worldwide, 3% of women of childbearing age rely on withdrawal as their primary method of contraception. Regional popularity of the method varies widely, from a low of 1% on the African continent to 16% in Western Asia. (Data from surveys during the late 1990s).{{cite paper |title=Family Planning Worldwide: 2002 Data Sheet |publisher=Population Reference Bureau |year=2002 |url=http://www.prb.org/pdf/FamPlanWorldwide_Eng.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2006-09-14 }} In the United States, studies have indicated 56% of women of reproductive age have had a partner use withdrawal. In 2002, 2.5% were using withdrawal as their primary method of contraception.{{cite journal | last= Chandra |first=A | coauthors = Martinez GM, Mosher WD, Abma JC, Jones J. |title=Fertility, Family Planning, and Reproductive Health of U.S. Women: Data From the 2002 National Survey of Family Growth |publisher=National Center for Health Statistics | journal = Vital Health Stat | volume = 23 | issue = 25 |year=2005 |url=http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/series/sr_23/sr23_025.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2007-05-20 }} See Tables 53 and 56. == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |author=Jones RK, Fennell J, Higgins JA, Blanchard K |title=Better than nothing or savvy risk-reduction practice? The importance of withdrawal |journal=Contraception |volume=79 |issue=6 |pages=407–10 |year=2009 |month=June |pmid=19442773 |doi=10.1016/j.contraception.2008.12.008 |url=http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/journals/reprints/Contraception79-407-410.pdf |accessdate=2009-07-23 |format=PDF}} == See also == * [[Coitus reservatus]] * [[Cum shot]] * [[Onanism]] {{Birth control methods}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coitus Interruptus}} [[Category:Methods of birth control]] [[Category:Contraception for males]] [[ca:Coitus interruptus]] [[cs:Přerušovaná soulož]] [[da:Afbrudt samleje]] [[de:Coitus interruptus]] [[et:Katkestatud suguühe]] [[es:Coitus interruptus]] [[eo:Interrompita koito]] [[fr:Coït interrompu]] [[it:Coito interrotto]] [[lt:Nutrauktoji sueitis]] [[nl:Coitus interruptus]] [[ja:膣外射精]] [[pl:Stosunek przerywany]] [[pt:Coito interrompido]] [[ru:Прерванный половой акт]] [[sk:Prerušovaná súlož]] [[sl:Coitus interruptus]] [[fi:Keskeytetty yhdyntä]] [[sv:Coitus interruptus]]
